page.title: 08River Tamar _ Wild Life
page.content: The river{landscape}, with its mud flats and creeks, encourages many birds, including Herons, Shags, Hawks, Waders and Gulls; also the rare Avocet. The number of Swans has declined, owing to poisoning by fishermen's lead weights, but attempts are now being made to obviate this tragedy. Birds are bred in the marshes at Egypt Bay for the{recreation}of duck shooting. In autumn, at low tide, Grey Squirrels cross the river from Clifton to Hanging Cliff woods near Hole's Hole to gather nuts and sun themselves on the beach. Other{wild {life}includes a large selection of Butterflies and Moths. Wild flowers grow in abundance, including Teasels. The{trade}in Narcissi for market commenced at Hole's Hole, and wild Narcissi still flower in the hedges there.
